responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Improper Certificate Validation
    analysis: |
      The ECXSdk class does not properly validate the server's SSL/TLS certificate when the 'production' flag is set to false. In this case, it uses a custom SSLConnectionSocketFactory that allows all hostnames and trusts self-signed certificates without proper validation:

      SSLContextBuilder builder = new SSLContextBuilder();
      builder.loadTrustMaterial(null, new TrustSelfSignedStrategy());
      SSLConnectionSocketFactory sslsf = new SSLConnectionSocketFactory(builder.build(),SSLSocketFactory.ALLOW_ALL_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER);
      
      This means the client could end up connecting to a malicious server impersonating the real server, enabling man-in-the-middle attacks that compromise the confidentiality and integrity of the HTTPS connection.
    cwe: CWE-295
    function_names:
      - _processRESTRequest
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/com/catalogic/ecx/sdk/ECXSdk.java
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Missing Access Control on Jenkins Job Configuration 
    analysis: |  
      The DescriptorImpl class, which defines the configuration options for the Jenkins plugin, does not seem to have any access control checks on who can configure the plugin. Any user with Job/Configure permissions on a Jenkins job using this plugin can potentially provide ECX credentials, URLs etc.
      
      This could allow lower privileged Jenkins users to obtain credentials for the integrated ECX server or make the Jenkins server interact with arbitrary URLs. There should be additional access control limiting the configuration of this sensitive plugin only to Jenkins administrators.
    cwe: CWE-862
    function_names:
      - DescriptorImpl
    filenames: 
      - src/main/java/com/catalogic/ecxjenkins/ecxjenkins/ECXCDMBuilder.java
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Improper Certificate Validation
Missing Access Control on Jenkins Job Configuration
leads.analysis:
The DescriptorImpl class, which defines the configuration options for the Jenkins plugin, does not seem to have any access control checks on who can configure the plugin. Any user with Job/Configure permissions on a Jenkins job using this plugin can potentially provide ECX credentials, URLs etc.

This could allow lower privileged Jenkins users to obtain credentials for the integrated ECX server or make the Jenkins server interact with arbitrary URLs. There should be additional access control limiting the configuration of this sensitive plugin only to Jenkins administrators.
